<h2>Distinguishing Features</h2>

A rarely-noticed but seemingly weedy species of disturbed soils, S. texanus is amongst the most charismatic of liverworts in the region on account of its abundant, submillimeter &quot;balloons&quot;. These structures actually enclose the reproductive organs, with the underlying leaves of the plant even less distinct, even with a hand lens.  

<h2>Similar species</h2>

No other bryophyte in the region resembles this species. 

<h2>Habitat</h2>

Seasonally saturated and frequently disturbed fine soils in open areas at low elevations.

<h2>Associated species</h2>

Gemmabryum barnesii, Plagiomnium cuspidatu,. Cephaloziella divaricata
